{{Infobox person | name= '''Alastair Galpin''' | image= AlastairGalpin.jpg | caption= November 2009 | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1974|4| }} | birth_place = [[East London, Eastern Cape|East London]], [[South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = National Diploma in Forestry ([[Port Elizabeth]] Technikon, South Africa)
BSc in Human Geography (University of Auckland, [[New Zealand]]) | occupation = Breaking World Records, Environmental supporter | alias = | title = | family = Norman Galpin, father | spouse = | children = | relatives = [[Ernest Edward Galpin]] | credits = Second Biggest World Record Breaker of the Decade 2000-2009 ([[Guinness World Records]]) | URL = http://www.worldrecordchase.com }} '''Alastair Galpin''' (born 1974, [[East London, Eastern Cape|East London]], [[South Africa]]) is the 2nd biggest Guinness World Records breaker of the [[2000s (decade)|2000s decade]],[[Guinness Book of World Records]] (2010), p. 7 breaking 38 World Records, behind [[Ashrita Furman]]. He immigrated to New Zealand in 2002, and says that his career in Record Breaking was inspired when he met champion rally driver, Simon Evans, in Kenya in 1998. ==World records== Alastair Galpin has broken over 85 world records for feats including having the most [[snail]]s on the face (eight in 10 seconds{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/35632|title=Snails ooze into record book|work=[[Fairfax New Zealand]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}}) and the most [[rubber-band]]s stretched over the face (62 in one minute). He also holds the most [[Postage stamp|stamp]]s licked (57 in one minute),{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10542402|title=A life less ordinary|last=Bridgeman|first=Shelley|date=2008-11-08|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}} loudest clap, and the fastest time to peel and eat three kiwifruit.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1859037,00.html |title=A Brief History Of Guinness World Records |last=Altman |first=Alex |date=2008-11-14 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=21 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919112129/http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0%2C8599%2C1859037%2C00.html |archivedate=19 September 2010 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/news_national_story_skin/1229997 |title=Record breaker hugs the limelight |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=21 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613221822/http://tvnz.co.nz/view/news_national_story_skin/1229997 |archivedate=13 June 2011 }} Galpin is also the holder of the Guinness World Record for the most hugs in one hour in Civic Square, [[Wellington, New Zealand]] on 13 July 2007 (624 hugs){{cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/HL0707/S00147.htm|title=No Need For Drugs When You Have 624 Hugs|last=Smith|first=Kelly|date=2007-07-13|work=[[Scoop (website)|Scoop]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}} and achieved three new Guinness World Records at the [[Guinness World Records]] Day 2009 for Champagne-cork spitting, coin blowing, and Malteser (malt ball) spitting.{{cite web|url=http://community.guinnessworldrecords.com/_Guinness-World-Records-Day-2009/video/842873/7691.html|title=Guinness World Records Day 2009|work=[[Guinness World Records]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}} Along with [[New Zealander]] Don Purdon, Galpin commenced an attempt at the longest hand-shake at 8pm EST on Friday 14 January 2011 in [[Times Square|New York Times Square]]. After 33 hours, three minutes, they had smashed the [[Handshake#Records|existing record]] by more than 17 hours{{cite web|url=http://www.worldrecordsacademy.org/society/longest_Handshake_Team_New_Zealand_and_Team_Nepal_set_world_record_112070.html |title=Longest Handshake: Team New Zealand and Team Nepal set world record |publisher=Worldrecordsacademy.org |date=2011-01-18 |accessdate=2012-08-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldrecordchase.com/achieved-records.html |title=World records accredited to Alastair Galpin (the second most successful world record breaker) |publisher=Worldrecordchase.com |date=2011-01-14 |accessdate=2012-08-05}}{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz//national-news/kiwis-break-world-record-handshake-4000587 |title=Kiwis break world record for a handshake |date=17 January 2011 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=16 September 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/close-up/record-handshake-holder-4002624/video |title=World record handshake holders |date=19 January 2011 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=16 September 2011}} and shared the record with [[Nepal]]ese brothers Rohit and Santosh Timilsina.http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90031342?%20Nepali%20brothers%20share%20world%20record%20for%20longest%20handshake Galpin's drive to assist non-profits lies in his awareness of escalating environmental and social degradation around the world. This awareness of his has been supported by Professor Noam Chomsky.http://www.worldrecordchase.com/opinionpiece.html {| class=wikitable |- ! style="width:245px;"|Event ! style="width:225px;"|Record ! style="width:220px;"|Location and Date |- | The loudest clap || 113 dBA || University of Auckland, New Zealand, November 2, 2008http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Loudest-clap/112835.htm |- | The fastest time to butter 10 slices of bread || 52.42 seconds || Pt Chevalier, Auckland, New Zealand, on 3 December 2009http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Fastest-time-to-butter-10-slices-of-bread/121738.htm |- | Longest full-body massage || 25 hours 4 minutes || South Kalimantan, Indonesia, November 2015 |- | The furthest champagne cork spit || 7.23 m || Fremantle, Perth, Australia, November 2013 |- | Tallest silverbeet plant || 363.5 cm || Auckland, New Zealand in 2008 [http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/tallest-silverbeet-plant2008.html Retrieved 17 May 2012.] |- | The most high fives in one minute || 76 || Trusts Stadium, Waitakere, Auckland, New Zealand, on 14 November 2009http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Most-high-fives-in-one-minute/122144.htm |- | The most lit candles in the mouth || 8 || Lo Show dei Record, Milan, Italy, on 15 March 2011http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Most-lit-candles-in-the-mouth/122148.htm |- | Largest bottle cap sculpture (shared) || 19,205 caps || Auckland, New Zealand in 2010 [http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/largest-bottle-cap-rugby-ball-sculpture2010.html Retrieved 17 May 2012.] |- | The most gloves put on one hand in one minute || 13 || Britomart Transport Centre, Auckland, New Zealand, on 12 November 2009http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Most-gloves-put-on-one-hand-in-one-minute/122151.htm |- | The most baseballs held in the hand (palm down) || 4 || Old Homestead, Auckland, New Zealand, on 28 April 2007http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Most-baseballs-held-in-the-hand-(palm-down)/107348.htm |- | The most side jumps (alternating each leg) achieved in a minute || 90 || The Warehouse shop in Sylvia Park, Auckland, New Zealand, on 27 October 2007.http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Most-side-jumps-in-one-minute/108202.htm |- | Furthest surface journey in a male chastity device || 4,894.6 km || Borneo, Indonesia, in November 2014 |- | Most M&M pretzels moved with a straw in 1 minute || 62 || Auckland, New Zealand, on 24 September 2012 |- | Largest cartoon (shared) || 862.8 square metres || Auckland, New Zealand in November 2006 [http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/largest-cartoon2006.html Retrieved 19 May 2012.] |- | The farthest coin flick || 12.11 m (39 ft 8 in) || Britomart Transport Centre, Auckland, New Zealand, on 12 November 2009http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/Search/Details/Farthest-coin-flicking-distance/122147.htm |} ==Charitable awareness raising== Galpin seeks to raise awareness - and sometimes raise funds - for social and environmental causes.{{cite web|url=http://community.guinnessworldrecords.com/service/displayKickPlace.kickAction?u=1597368&as=7691&b= |title=Alastair - Guinness World Records Member - Home of the Longest, Shortest, Fastest, Tallest facts and feats |publisher=Community.guinnessworldrecords.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-05}} He uses various methods to spread knowledge of environmental issues, including referring to issues of global concern in his website’s stories,{{cite web|url=http://www.worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/most-aa-batteries-held-in-hand2011.html |title=Achieving the Guinness World Record™ for the Most AA batteries held in the hand: 44 | Alastair Galpin |publisher=Worldrecordchase.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-05}} and during his motivational storytelling in schools.{{cite web|url=http://worldrecordchase.com/storytelling.html |title=Storytelling - world record breaker Alastair Galpin |publisher=Worldrecordchase.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-05}} His opinion piece, titled 'Human Application of Consciousness' - while not directly related to world record-breaking, explains Galpin's drive to contribute to the struggle for a truly sustainable future for mankind and other life on earth. He does so by collaborating with non-profits and organisations on projects of varying degrees of social and environmental importance.[http://worldrecordchase.com/opinionpiece.html Retrieved 7 October 2012.] Among his more noteworthy charitable efforts are the greatest height to drop gambling machines as a statement against gambling harm,[http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/greatest-height-drop-gambling-machine2007.html Retrieved 19 May 2012.] the largest bowl of soup (shared) to show healthy eating in disadvantaged communities,[http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/largest-bowl-of-soup2008.html Retrieved 19 May 2012.] and the most radio interviews in a suspended cage to bring media attention to the issue of problem gambling.[http://worldrecordchase.com/records-stories/most-suspended-radio-interviews2009.html Retrieved 19 May 2012.] ==Unusual feats== His activities were played down by some US websites covering "most ridiculous" and "least impressive" world records and he has also attracted US television coverage for similar reasons.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=2641636&page=1|title=Kiss, Cook, and Dance for World Record's Day|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}} Among other print media, [[The Citizen (South Africa)|The Citizen]] has featured his work.{{cite web|url=http://www.citizen.co.za/citizen/content/en/citizen/lifestyle-features?oid=252418&sn=Detail&pid=146849&For-the-record |title=The Citizen Online | For the record - Lifestyle |publisher=Citizen.co.za |date= |accessdate=2012-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123110258/http://www.citizen.co.za/citizen/content/en/citizen/lifestyle-features?oid=252418&sn=Detail&pid=146849&For-the-record |archivedate=2012-01-23 }} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.worldrecordchase.com/ Official website of Alastair Galpin] * [http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0904/S00036.htm It's Auckland Cranes & The Caged Alastair Galpin (Scoop)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Galpin, Alastair}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:World record holders]]

{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{advert|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Astro Malaysia Holdings Berhad | logo = Logo of Astro Malaysia Holdings Bhd.svg | logo_size = 200px | traded_as = {{MYX|6399}} | type = Publicly traded company | ISIN = MYL6399OO009 | foundation = 1996 | location = [[Technology Park Malaysia]], [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia | key_people = [[Zaki Azmi]], Chairman
[[Rohana Rozhan]], CEO | num_employees = 4,454 (2013){{cite web |url= http://www.astromalaysia.com.my/Portals/39/pdf/AMH-AR13-ENG.pdf|title=go beyond: annual report 2013|publisher=Astro Malaysia Holdings Bhd|accessdate=12 April 2014 |format=PDF}} | industry = [[Mass media]] | parent = [[Astro Holdings Sdn Bhd]] and [[Khazanah Nasional]] | area_served = [[South East Asia]] | products = [[Pay television]]
[[Broadcasting]]
[[Publishing]] | revenue = {{increase}} [[Malaysian ringgit|RM]] 4,790.7 [[million]] (2014){{cite web |url= http://www.astromalaysia.com.my/Portals/39/pdf/AMH-4QFY14-report.pdf|title= Quarterly Report for the Fourth Quarter Ended 31 January 2014|date=31 March 2014 |publisher=Astro Malaysia Holdings Bhd|accessdate=12 April 2014 |format=PDF}} | operating_income = {{decrease}} RM 569.2 million (2014) | net_income = {{increase}} RM 447.8 million (2014) | homepage = {{URL|www.astromalaysia.com.my}} }} {{confused|Astro (television)}} '''Astro Malaysia Holdings Berhad''' ({{myx|6399}}) is a Malaysian media and entertainment holding company that began as a paid digital satellite [[satellite radio|radio]] and [[satellite television|television]] service, [[Astro (satellite TV)|Astro]]. The company is owned by '''Astro Holdings Sendirian Berhad''' which also owns '''Astro Overseas Limited'''. == Corporate Information == Astro Malaysia Holdings Berhad is a company incorporated in [[Malaysia]] with its principal place of business at the Administration Building of the All Asia Broadcast Centre, located in [[Technology Park Malaysia]]. Since its establishment, it expanded to provide management services to its subsidiaries. The company is dedicated and engaged in content creation, aggregation and distribution activities, including the provision of direct-to-home subscription television, radio broadcasting services, library licensing, multimedia interactive services, [[magazine]] publishing, Malaysian [[film production]], talent management, creation of [[computer animation]], interactive content and television content distribution. It is Malaysia's largest pay television provider. == History == In 1996, a state-of-the-art digital All Asia Broadcast Centre was constructed at [[Bukit Jalil]]. At the same time, the [[MEASAT]] satellite network began with the launch of MEASAT 1. The new [[pay television|pay-television service]] named Astro launched and started broadcasting with 22 [[television channel]]s and 8 music channels. The launch of more MEASAT satellites from 1998 onward allowed Astro to begin expanding its services. == Timeline History == * 1996 — The Astro subscription service begins and named '''ASTRO All Asia Network plc''' was incorporated in [[England and Wales]], and [[Japan]]. * 1997 — Achieved [[MSC Malaysia|Multimedia Super Corridor]] status. * 2003 — Astro acquired [[Celestial Pictures]] and Philippine-based animation studio. * April 2005 — the company acquired [[THR.fm|Time Highway Radio]] radio network, which is Malaysia's private Indian radio station. Astro launched Malaysia's first subscription IPTV channels based on content licensed from Goal TV (English Premier League Soccer club TV for Liverpool, Chelsea and others) and Akademi Fantasia, a localised version of an Endemol's Fame Academy. * June 2005 — Astro acquired Yes Television (Hong Kong) Limited and Goal TV Asia Limited to distribute broadband and broadcast content in the region. * 2006 — Rohana Rozhan CFO of AAAN elected as CEO of the Astro Malaysia and Brunei-based pay TV businesses. * 2006 — Astro launches [[Astro MAX]], Malaysia's first [[Personal video recorder|PVR]] service. * 2007 — Astro launches VoD services, adding Hong Kong [[TVB]] dramas to on-demand content. (Astro On Demand is not a real VoD service as customers cannot request for videos at any time, but can follow multi-broadcasting during a certain period of the day on different channels) * 28 April 2008 - [[Astro cảm xúc]] was first launched in Vietnam as a product between [[Ho Chi Minh City Television Cable Center|HTVC]] and [[Astro (satellite TV)|Astro]]. Six months later, ''Astro cảm xúc'' appeared on [[Vietnam Cable Television]]. * 14 June 2010 - AAAN was de-listed from the Main Market of Bursa Malaysia Securities Berhad following a successful take-over offer by Usaha Tegas Sdn Bhd and company name has been changed to '''Astro Holdings Sdn Bhd''' * 2011 - Established ASTRO Malaysia Holdings Berhad as preparation for re-list to the Main Market of Bursa Malaysia. * 2012 - ASTRO Malaysia Holdings Berhad listed to the Main Market of Bursa Malaysia. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.astromalaysia.com.my/ Astro Malaysia Holdings Investor Relations Website] * [http://www.astro.com.my Astro Malaysia Website] {{Astro Holdings Sdn Bhd}} {{MSC Malaysia}} {{FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI constituents}} [[Category:Media companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Malaysian companies established in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Malaysia]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Malaysia Exchange]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Media companies of Malaysia]] [[Category:Holding companies of Malaysia]] [[Category:Astro All Asia Networks plc| ]] [[Category:Companies based in Kuala Lumpur]]

{{Infobox NRHP | name = Bethany Congregational Church | nrhp_type = | image = Bethany Congregational Church (Thomasville, Georgia).jpg | caption = | location= 112 Lester St.
[[Thomasville, Georgia]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|49|13|N|83|59|11|W|region:US-GA_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = USA Georgia#USA | built = 1891 | architecture = | added = March 7, 1985 | area = {{convert|1.2|acre}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 85000453{{NRISref|2009a}} }} '''Bethany Congregational Church''' is a [[United Church of Christ]] house of worship located in [[Thomasville, Georgia]] in south Georgia's [[Thomas County, Georgia|Thomas County]]. It was founded on February 1, 1891, by the [[American Missionary Association]] as the chapel and worship center of the Allen Normal and Industrial School, an educational institution for [[African American]] students. The school operated from 1885 to 1933, and the church remained after the school property was razed in 1935.{{Cite book|url= | title=African American Historic Places |author=Beth L. Savage | publisher=Wiley | page=1198 | year=1994 | isbn=0-471-14345-6}} In 1985, the church was added to the [[National Register of Historical Places]].{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=85000453}}|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory/Nomination: Bethany Congregational Church |publisher=[[National Park Service]]|author=Carolyn Brooks |date=January 21, 1985 |accessdate=March 6, 2017 }} with {{NRHP url|id=85000453|photos=y|title=six photos from 1984}} Civil rights leader [[Andrew Young]], who earned a divinity degree from [[Hartford Theological Seminary]] in Connecticut, accepted the pastorate of Bethany Congregational Church in 1955.[http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/government-politics/andrew-young-b-1932] He served as pastor of [[Evergreen Congregational Church and School|Evergreen Congregational Church]] in adjacent [[Grady County, Georgia|Grady County]] during 1957-59; Evergreen is also NRHP-listed. ==References== {{reflist}} {{National Register of Historic Places}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Thomas County, Georgia]] [[Category:Churches on the National Register of Historic Places in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:United Church of Christ churches in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Churches completed in 1891]] [[Category:19th-century United Church of Christ church buildings]] [[Category:African-American history of Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Thomas County, Georgia]] {{GeorgiaUS-church-stub}} {{GeorgiaUS-NRHP-stub}} {{Africandiaspora-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=October 2011}}
{{Infobox book | image = La Fontaine - Tales and Novels in verse - v2 p130.jpg | caption = Illustration by Charles Eisen for the poem "The Devil of Pope-Fig Island" | alt = Perretta, smiling, exposes herself to a horrified imp. | author = [[Jean de La Fontaine]] | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | genre = [[Ribaldry]] | publisher = Claude Barbin | pub_date = 1665 | english_pub_date = 1735 | media_type = Print | pages = 94 | oclc = 458206970 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = Parution des deux premiers contes: Joconde, et Le cocu battu et content | followed_by = 3 contes: Les frères de Catalogne, l'Ermite et Mazet de Lamporechio }} '''''Contes et nouvelles en vers''''' ({{Lang-en|Tales and Novellas in Verse}}) is an [[anthology]] of various [[ribald]] [[Short story|short stories]] and [[novella]]s collected and versified from [[prose]] by [[Jean de La Fontaine]]. Claude Barbin of Paris published the collection in 1665.
La Fontaine drew from several French and Italian works of the 15th and 16th centuries, among them ''[[The Decameron]]'' of [[Giovanni Boccaccio]], [[Ludovico Ariosto]]'s ''[[Orlando Furioso]]'', [[Antoine de la Sale]]'s collection ''[[Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles]]'', and the work of [[Bonaventure des Périers]].
==Contents==
Book 1
{{Inc-lit|date=October 2011}} #"Joconde", ''Orlando Furioso'' XXVIII, 4ff #"Le Cocu batu, et content", ''Decameron'' VII.7 #"Le Mari confesseur" #"Le Savetier" #"La Paysan" #"Le Muletier" #"La Servante justifie'e" #"La Gageure des trois commeres", ''Decameron'' VII.8 and VII.9 (with some modifications) #"Le Calendrier des vieillards" #"A femme avare galant escroc" #"On ne s'avise jamais de tout" #"Le gascon puni" #"La Fiancée du roi de garbe" #"La Coupe enchante'e" #"Le Faucon" #"Le Petit chien" #"Paté d'anguille" #"Le Magnifique" #"La Matrone d'ephese" #"Belphegor" #"La Clochette" #"Le Glouton" #"Les Deux Amis" #"Le Juge de Mesle" #"Alis Malade" #"Le Baiser Rendu" #"Soeur Jeanne" #"Imitation d'Anacreon" #"L'Amour mouille" #"Les Oies de frère Philippe" #"Richard Minutolo" #"Les cordeliers de Catalogne" #"Le Villageois qui cherche son veau"
Book 2
#"Le Berceau" #"L'oraison de Saint Julien" #"L'Anneau d"ahns Carvel" #"L'ermite" #"Mazet de Lamporechio" #"La mandragore" #"Les remois" #"La courtisane amoureuse" #"Nicaise" #"Comment l'esprit vient aux filles" #"L'abbesse malade" #"Le troquers" #"Le cas de conscience" #"Le diable de Papefiguiere" #"Feronde ou le purgatoire" #"Le psautier" #"Le roi Candaule et le maitre en droit" #"Les lunettes" #"Le cuvier" #"La chose impossible" #"Le tableau" #"Le Bat" #"Le faiseur d'oreilles et le raccommodeur de moules" #"Le fleuve Scamandre" #"La confidente sans le savoir ou le stratageme" #"Le remede" #"Les aveux indiscrets" #"Le contrat" #"Les quiproquo" #"La couturiere" #"Le gascon" #"La cruche" #"Promettre est un et tenir est un autre" #"Le rossignol"
==See also== *[[15th century in literature]] *[[16th century in literature]] *[[17th century in poetry]] *[[17th-century French literature]]
==External links== *{{Internet Archive|contesetnouvelle00lafo}}

revision.text:
[[File:Eurasia (orthographic projection).svg|thumb|right|Eurasia]] This is a list of the '''extreme points of [[Eurasia]]''', the points that are farther north, south, east or west than any other location on the [[continent]]. Some of these locations are open to debate, owing to the diverse definitions of Europe and Asia.
Mainland Eurasia is entirely located within the northern hemisphere and mostly within the eastern hemisphere, yet it touches the western hemisphere on both extremes. Thus, both the easternmost and westernmost points of Eurasia are in the western hemisphere. Mainland Eurasia crosses 200° of [[longitude]] and 76° of [[latitude]] north to south.
==Extremes of Eurasia, including islands==
* '''Northernmost Point''' — [[Cape Fligeli]], [[Rudolf Island]], [[Franz Josef Land]], [[Russia]] (81°50'N, 59°14'E) * '''Southernmost Point''' — [[Dana Island, Rote Ndao]], [[Indonesia]]<ref name="MONK_7">{{cite book |last=Monk, |first=K.A. |author2=Fretes, Y. |author3=Reksodiharjo-Lilley, G. |title=The Ecology of Nusa Tenggara and Maluku |publisher=Periplus Editions Ltd. |date=1996 |page=7|location=Hong Kong |isbn=962-593-076-0}}</ref> (11°00'S, 122°52'E) *'''Westernmost point''' — The [[Capelinhos]] Volcano, [[Faial Island]], [[Azores Islands]], [[Portugal]] (28° 50′ 00″ W), the westernmost point of the [[Eurasian Plate]] above sea level. The culturally European island nation of [[Iceland]] is also on the boundary of the plates; its westernmost point is [[Bjargtangar]] (24° 32′ 03″ W). * '''Easternmost point''' — [[Big Diomede]], [[Russia]] (65°46'N, 169°03'W). The [[International Date Line]] runs between the Russian Big Diomede and the neighbouring U.S.-governed [[Little Diomede]].
==Extremes of the Eurasian mainland==
* Northernmost Point — [[Cape Chelyuskin]], [[Russia]] (77°44'N, 104°15'E) * Southernmost Point — [[Cape Piai]], [[Malaysia]] (1°15'N, 103°30'E) * Westernmost Point — [[Cabo da Roca]], [[Portugal]] (38°46'N, 9°29'W) * Easternmost Point — [[Cape Dezhnev]], [[Russia]] (66°4'N, 169°39'W)
==Other== * Highest altitude: — [[Mount Everest]], [[Nepal]] and [[China]] — {{convert|8848|m|0|abbr=on}} * Lowest point on dry land: — The shore of the [[Dead Sea]], [[Israel]] and [[Jordan]], {{convert|418|m|0|abbr=on}} below sea level. ''See [[List of places on land with elevations below sea level]].'' * Farthest from the ocean: — A place near [[Hoxtolgay]] in [[China]] ({{Coord|46|17|N|86|40|E|name=Continental Pole of Inaccessibility}}) {{convert|2,645|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the nearest coastline. ''See [[Pole of inaccessibility]].''
== See also == * [[Geography of Europe]] * [[Geography of Asia]] * [[Extreme points of Europe]] * [[Extreme points of Asia]] * [[Extreme points of Afro-Eurasia]] * [[Extreme points of Earth]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{prose|date=July 2017}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2017}} '''''Groupe de Chasse''''' or '''''groupe de chasse''''' (usually abbreviated as '''GC''') is the [[French language]] term for "[[fighter aircraft|fighter]] [[group (air force)|group]]" or "fighter [[wing (military unit)|wing]]". More literal translations include "pursuit group" (the US term for fighter groups prior to 1942) and "hunting group" (similar to the German language ''[[Jagdgruppe]]'' or ''JG'').
==Composition== A ''group de chasse'' may include one to four ''[[escadrille]]s'', each of which comprises 10–12 aircraft. The commanding officer of a ''GC'' is usually a ''[[Commandant]]'', ''[[Lieutenant-colonel]]'' or ''[[Colonel]]''.
==Units== Specific units known by the name ''groupe de chasse'' include:
;''[[Groupe de Chasse (Belgium)]]'' :a Belgian unit of World War I
;''[[Groupe de Chasse Polonaise I/145]]'': a Polish unit fighting alongside France in 1940
===France=== Including: * ''[[Armee de l'Air]]'' * ''[[Vichy French Air Force|Armée de l'air de Vichy]]'' * ''[[Forces Aériennes Françaises Libres]]''
Units ;''[[Groupe de Chasse I/1]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse I/3]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse I/8]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse I/13]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/1]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/5]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/6]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/8]] '' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/9]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse II/10]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III]]'' (''Normandie-Niemen'') ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/2]]'' (''GC Alsace'') ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/3]]'' ;''[[Normandie-Niemen]]'' (also known as ''GC III'') ;''[[Groupe de Chasse Alsace]]'' (''GC III/2'') ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/6]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/9]] ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/10]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse III/13]]'' ;''[[Groupe de Chasse IV/2]]'' (''GC Île-de-France'') ;''[[Groupe de Chasse Île-de-France]]'' (also known as ''GC IV/2'')
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = Jiroemon Kimura (ODN News).png | caption = Kimura on his 115th birthday on 19 April 2012 | native_name = 木村 次郎右衛門 | native_name_lang = ja | birth_name = {{Nihongo|三宅 金治郎|Miyake Kinjiro}} | birth_date = 19 April 1897 | birth_place = [[Kyōtango|Kamiukawa]], Japan | death_date = 12 June 2013
(aged {{age in years and days|1897|4|19|2013|6|12}}) | death_place = [[Kyōtango]], Japan | nationality = Japanese | ethnicity = | occupation = Retired postal worker, farmer{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8451161/Worlds-oldest-man-celebrates-114th-birthday.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=World's oldest man celebrates 114th birthday|date=April 19, 2011}} | known for = * Oldest man ever * Only man in history who undisputedly reached age 116 * Oldest living person (17 December 2012 – 12 June 2013) | parents = Morizo and Fusa Miyake | spouse = Yae Kimura (1904–1978) (m. ?–1978; her death) | children = 7 }} {{Nihongo|'''Jiroemon Kimura'''|木村 次郎右衛門|Kimura Jirōemon|19 April 1897 – 12 June 2013}} was a Japanese [[supercentenarian]]. He became the [[list of the verified oldest men|oldest verified male in history]] on 28 December 2012, at the age of 115 years and 253 days when he surpassed the age of [[Christian Mortensen]] who died in 1998, and also became the first and so far the only man who indisputably reached 116 years of age, being 116 years, 54 days old at the time of his death from natural causes on 12 June 2013, in a hospital in his hometown of [[Kyōtango]], [[Kyoto Prefecture]], Japan. He was the last verified living man born in the 19th century.{{cite web |url=http://japandailypress.com/worlds-oldest-man-ever-turns-116-in-kyoto-as-his-health-is-studied-1927336 |title=World’s oldest man ever turns 116 in Kyoto as his health is studied |work=The Japan Daily Press |date=April 15, 2013 |accessdate=April 19, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605022257/http://japandailypress.com/worlds-oldest-man-ever-turns-116-in-kyoto-as-his-health-is-studied-1927336 |archive-date=June 5, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}
- {{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130419-worlds-oldest-person-turns-116-japan|title=World's oldest person turns 116 in Japan|work=FRANCE 24 International News|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
- {{cite web|agency=Agence France-Presse|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/et-cetera/worlds-oldest-person-jiroemon-kimura-turns-116-in-japan/articleshow/19628476.cms|title=World's oldest person Jiroemon Kimura turns 116 in Japan|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-61IXYqFUHo|title=World's oldest man ever turns 116|publisher=YouTube|author=Zoominuk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/lifestyle/view/from-horseless-carriages-to-iphone5s-the-world-during-116-year-old-jiroemon-kimuras-lifetime|title=From horseless carriages to iPhone5s: The world during 116-year-old Jiroemon Kimura’s lifetime|date=June 9, 2013|accessdate=June 11, 2013}}
- {{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-06-11/jiroemon-kimura-oldest-man-in-recorded-history-dies-at-age-116.html|title=Jiroemon Kimura, Oldest Man in Recorded History, Dies at 116|date=June 12, 2013|accessdate=June 14, 2013}} Kimura became the [[List of Japanese supercentenarians|oldest living man in Japan]] upon the death of [[Tomoji Tanabe]] on 19 June 2009,{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20090622a3.html |title=Japan's oldest man says 'thank you very much' |work=Japan Times |date=June 22, 2009 |accessdate=October 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rWEJyXTY?url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20090622a3.html |archivedate=July 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} the [[Oldest people#Chronological list of the verified oldest living man since 1962|world's oldest living man]] upon the death of [[Walter Breuning]] on 15 April 2011,{{efn|Breuning died 14 April 2011, 3:30pm [[Mountain Time Zone|MDT]]. However, in Japan, where Kimura lived, the date was already 15 April 2011 ([[Japan Standard Time|JST]]).}}{{cite web|last=Volz|first=Matt|title=Walter Breuning, World's Oldest Man, Dies In Montana At 114|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/14/walter-breuning-worlds-oldest-man-dies_n_849486.html|work=Huffington Post|date=April 14, 2011|accessdate=December 17, 2012}}{{cite web|author=Breaking News Online Team |url=http://www.breakingnewsonline.net/world/8086-jiroemon-kimura-becomes-worlds-oldest-man-at-114.html?amp |title=Jiroemon Kimura becomes World's Oldest Man at 114 |work=Breaking News Online |date=April 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003180534/http://www.breakingnewsonline.net/world/8086-jiroemon-kimura-becomes-worlds-oldest-man-at-114.html?amp |archivedate=October 3, 2011 |df= }} the [[List of Japanese supercentenarians#Chronological list of the oldest living person in Japan since 1975|oldest living person in Japan]] upon the death of [[Chiyono Hasegawa]] on 2 December 2011, and the [[Oldest people#Chronological list of the verified oldest living person since 1955|world's oldest living person]] upon the death of Dina Manfredini on 17 December 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.kcrg.com/news/local/115-year-old-Iowa-Woman-Dies-Was-Worlds-Oldest-Person-183804831.html |title=115-year-old Iowa Woman Dies, Was World's Oldest Person |work=KCRG-TV9 |date=December 17, 2012 |accessdate=December 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113022820/http://www.kcrg.com/news/local/115-year-old-Iowa-Woman-Dies-Was-Worlds-Oldest-Person-183804831.html |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }} until his own death. With Breuning's death, he was also the last living man born in the 1890s. He and Breuning were also the only verified men born in the 1800s who lived into the 2010s. ==Early life and education== Kimura was born as {{Nihongo|Kinjiro Miyake|三宅 金治郎|Miyake Kinjirō}}. According to records, he was born on 19 April 1897,{{cite web|title=Oldest Validated Living Supercentenarians |url=http://www.grg.org/Adams/E.HTM |work=[[Gerontology Research Group]] |accessdate=December 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.grg.org%2FAdams%2FE.HTM&date=2007-12-01 |archivedate=December 1, 2007 |df= }} in the [[fishing village]] of Kamiukawa, the third of six children born to farmers Morizo and Fusa Miyake.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-12-28/japanese-115-year-old-becomes-oldest-man-in-recorded-history.html |title=Japanese 115-Year-Old Becomes Oldest Man in History |work=Bloomberg |date=December 27, 2012 |accessdate=December 28, 2012 |last=Matsuyama |first=Kanoko |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DEyKFO46?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-12-28/japanese-115-year-old-becomes-oldest-man-in-recorded-history.html |archivedate=December 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} According to Kimura's nephew, Tamotsu Miyake, Kimura was actually born on 19 March 1897, but his birthday was instead recorded as 19 April 1897, by mistake in 1955 when records from neighboring towns were consolidated and redone. He finished school second in his class at age 14 and commenced working from local post offices around the age of 17. ==Marriage and career== In the 1920s, Kimura also worked as a government communications worker in [[Korea under Japanese rule]]. Upon returning from Korea, he married his neighbor, Yae Kimura (1904–1978). Since his wife's family lacked a male heir, he changed his name to Jiroemon Kimura, becoming the ninth member of the family to bear that name. He retired in 1962 at the age of 65, having worked in post offices for 45 years. After retiring he turned to farming until the age of 90. ==Personal life== Four of Kimura's siblings lived past the age of 90, and his youngest brother died at the age of 100. Kimura had 7 children (5 of whom survived him), 14 grandchildren (13 surviving), 25 great-grandchildren and 15 great-great-grandchildren.{{cite web|url= http://sankei.jp.msn.com/west/west_life/news/130419/wlf13041910510009-n1.htm|script-title= ja:「はいはい、ありがとう」長寿世界一の木村さんが１１６回目の誕生日|trans-title= World's oldest person, Kimura, celebrates 116th birthday|date= April 19, 2013|work= MSN Sankei News|publisher= The Sankei Shimbun & Sankei Digital|location= Japan|language= Japanese|accessdate= April 19, 2013|title= Archived copy|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130419043314/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/west/west_life/news/130419/wlf13041910510009-n1.htm|archive-date= April 19, 2013|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}} Kimura was health conscious and active.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=8544037 |title=Japan's century club swells to more than 40,000 |publisher=ABC News |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 3, 2009 |last=Yamaguchi |first=Mari |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rWEU7TEb?url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=8544037 |archivedate=July 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He woke up early in the morning and read newspapers with a magnifying glass. Also, he enjoyed talking to guests and followed live [[National Diet|parliamentary debates]] on television. According to him, small portions of food ([[hara hachi bun me]]) (腹八分目/はらはちぶんめ) were the key to a long and healthy life.{{cite web | url=http://www.natureworldnews.com/articles/2152/20130528/last-man-alive-born-1800s-celebrates-116th-birthday-video.htm | title=Last Man Alive to Have Been Born in 1800s Celebrates 116th Birthday | publisher=Nature World News | date=May 28, 2013 | accessdate=4 January 2015 | author=Kemsley, Tamarra}} Kimura resided in Kyōtango, Kyoto Prefecture, with his eldest son's widow, 83, and his grandson's widow, 59. On his 114th birthday on 19 April 2011, Kimura mentioned his survival of the 7.6 [[Richter magnitude scale|magnitude]] [[1927 Kita Tango earthquake]] that hit Kyoto and killed over 3,000 people.{{cite news |url=http://asienspiegel.ch/2011/04/der-alteste-mann-der-welt/ |work=Asienspiegel |date=April 20, 2011 |title=Der älteste Mann der Welt |language=de}} Being born in the year 30 of the [[Meiji period]], he lived in the reigns of [[List of Emperors of Japan|4 emperors]], and during the premierships of [[List of Prime Ministers of Japan|61 Japanese Prime Ministers]], from [[Matsukata Masayoshi]] to [[Shinzō Abe]]. In October 2012, Kimura was presented with a certificate from ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' Editor-in-Chief Craig Glenday, relating to Kimura's appearance in the 2013 edition of ''Guinness World Records'' book; this was the second year in a row Kimura was recognized as the oldest living man in the world, as he also appeared in the book the year before. During the meeting, Kimura said he spent most of his time in bed.{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/2012/10/worlds-oldest-living-man-welcomes-guinness-world-records-editor-to-his-home-45453/|title=Worlds oldest living man welcomes Guinness World Records editor to his home|work=Guinness World Records|date=October 15, 2012}}
- {{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19965280|title=New record for world's oldest man Jiroemon Kimura|work=BBC News|date=October 16, 2012}} On his 116th and final birthday, Kimura received many well-wishes, including a video message from Japan's Prime Minister Shinzō Abe. He was hospitalized for pneumonia on 11 May 2013. On 23 May 2013, when James Sisnett of [[Barbados]] died, Kimura became the last verified living man born in the 19th century. He died of natural causes in the hospital in his hometown of Kyōtango, western Japan, at 2:08 a.m. on 12 June 2013.{{cite web |url= http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/news/2013/06/12/kiji/K20130612005995560.html|script-title=ja:長寿世界一　１１６歳の木村次郎右衛門氏死去|trans-title=World's oldest person, Jiroemon Kimura, dies at 116 |date= June 12, 2013|work= Sponichi Annex|publisher= Sports Nippon Newspapers|location= Japan|language= Japanese|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130616061643/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/news/2013/06/12/kiji/K20130612005995560.html|archivedate=June 16, 2013 |accessdate= 11 February 2016|quote={{Nihongo|... died of old age at a hospital in Kyotango, Kyoto|老衰のため京都府京丹後市の病院で死去した}}}}{{cite web|author=Damien Fletcher |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/worlds-oldest-person-oldest-man-1947175 |title=World's oldest person and oldest man ever to live Jiroemon Kimura dies aged 116|work=Daily Mirror |date=June 12, 2013 |accessdate=January 4, 2014}} His funeral was held on 14 June 2013.{{cite news |url=http://www.kyoto-np.co.jp/politics/article/20130614000084 |script-title=ja:いつまでも「輝く宝」で　木村次郎右衛門さん告別式 |lang=ja |trans-title=Jiroemon Kimura's funeral – a sparkling jewel forever |date=14 June 2013 |newspaper=[[Kyoto Shimbun]] |access-date=20 October 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615030142/http://www.kyoto-np.co.jp/politics/article/20130614000084 |archive-date=15 June 2013 |dead-url=yes}} ==See also== * [[Oldest people]] * [[List of the oldest people by country]] * [[List of the verified oldest people]] * [[List of Japanese supercentenarians]] * [[Elderly people in Japan]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kimura, Jiroemon}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese farmers]] [[Category:Japanese supercentenarians]] [[Category:World record holders]] [[Category:Male supercentenarians]] [[Category:People from Kyoto Prefecture]] [[Category:Postal officials]]

{{coord|62.30207|N|9.60386|E|type:landmark_region:NO|display=title}} [[File:Kongsvoll fjellhage, informasjonstavle.jpg|thumb|300px|Kongsvoll Alpine Garden, information board]]
'''Kongsvoll Alpine Garden''' (''Kongsvoll fjellhage'') is a small botanical garden for alpine plants situated at [[Kongsvoll|Kongsvold Fjeldstue]], 890 [[Metres above sea level|masl]] at [[Dovrefjell]] in [[Central Norway]]. Most of the plants are local to Dovrefjell and adjacent mountain ranges in [[Trøndelag]] and [[Møre og Romsdal]]. The garden is administered by the [[NTNU University Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ntnu.edu/museum/kongsvoll-alpine-garden|title=Kongsvoll Alpine Garden|first=Christian|last=Fossen|website=www.ntnu.edu}}</ref>.
The garden is the only alpine botanical in [[Scandinavia]]<ref name="Kalseth">Kalseth, Randi G.: Den frodigste fjellhagen</ref>. Apart from local flora, the garden also display the most common [[vascular plant]]s from mountain ranges in central- and southern Norway. The garden contains a total of approx. 300 species of vascular plants, and in addition a number of [[mosses]] and [[lichen]]s.<ref>Fremstad, Eli: Kongsvoll fjellhage (NTNU, 2008)</ref>
The garden was created in 1992 by Simen Bretten, manager of the Kongsvoll Biolocial Station. It replaces an older garden established in 1924 by the botanist [[Thekla Resvoll]] at the then [[Kongsvoll Station]]. The older garden was originally administered by [[University of Oslo]] until 1975, and later by NTNU.
== Referfences == <references/>

Radio was founded by [[Nezavisne novine]] publishing house and newspapers on 1 June 1997.{{cite web|author1=www.nesradio.com|title=O nama, Nes radio|url=http://www.nesradio.com/index.php?modul=onama&poziv=nesradio|website=www.nesradio.com|accessdate=21 February 2016|language=Bosnian}} '''Nes Radio''' sister station intended for the local audience in [[Banja Luka]] is radio [[Nes Castra]]. ==Frequencys== The program is currently broadcast at 6 frequencys in 5 [[Bosnia]]n cities: * [[Sarajevo]] {{Frequency|87.7|[[MHz]]}} * [[Banja Luka]] {{Frequency|88.4|[[MHz]]}} * [[Banja Luka]] {{Frequency|106.4|[[MHz]]}} * [[Kotor Varoš]] {{Frequency|89.7|[[MHz]]}} * [[Tuzla]] {{Frequency|95.5|[[MHz]]}} * [[Bihać]] {{Frequency|99.3|[[MHz]]}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.nesradio.com Official website Nes Radio] * [http://cra.ba/bih/index.php?uid=1273787112 [[Communications Regulatory Agency of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]] == See also == *[[List of radio stations in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] {{coord missing|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} [[Category:Radio stations in Bosnia and Herzegovina|Banja Luka]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1997]] [[Category:Media in Banja Luka]] {{Europe-radio-station-stub}}

Australian forces [[Battle of Buna-Gona|attack Japanese positions near Buna]]. Members of the 2/12th Infantry Battalion advance as [[Stuart tank]]s from the 2/6th Armoured Regiment attack Japanese pillboxes. An upward-firing machine gun on the tank sprays treetops to clear them of snipers. (Photographer: George Silk).]] | caption = Australian forces [[Battle of Buna-Gona|attack Japanese positions near Buna]] | date = 23 January 1942 – August 1945 | place = [[New Guinea]] | coordinates = | map_type = | map_relief = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_marksize = | map_caption = | map_label = | territory = | result = Allied victory | combatants_header = | combatant1 = {{flag|Australia|size=23px}}

{{flagicon|Empire of Japan|naval}} [[Masatomi Kimura]] | units1 = | units2 = | strength1 = | strength2 = 350,000Tanaka 1980, p. ii. | casualties1 = 42,000 total[http://www.history.army.mil/brochures/new-guinea/ng.htm New Guinea: The US Army Campaigns of World War II]. 8,500 prior to January 1943, 24,000 between January 1943 and April 1944, and 9,500 from April 1944 to the end of the war. Retrieved 23 July 2015. * {{flagicon|US|1912}} 12,291 (4,684 killed)"Statistical and accounting branch office of the adjutant general p. 94" | casualties2 = 127,600 (mostly from disease and starvation)Fenton, Damien (1 June 2004). [http://ajrp.awm.gov.au/AJRP/remember.nsf/709e228818bdf765ca256a9a001dad4d/58ebd6d993e15ce8ca256d05002671fd How many died? (QnA)] Australian War Memorial. | notes = | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox New Guinea}} }} The '''New Guinea campaign''' of the [[Pacific War]] lasted from January 1942 until the end of the war in August 1945. During the initial phase in early 1942, the [[Empire of Japan]] invaded the [[Australia]]n-administered territories of the [[Territory of New Guinea|New Guinea Mandate]] (23 January) and [[Territory of Papua|Papua]] (8 March) and overran [[Dutch New Guinea|western New Guinea]] (beginning 29/30 March), which was a part of the [[Netherlands East Indies]]. During the second phase, lasting from late 1942 until the Japanese surrender, the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]]—consisting primarily of Australian and US forces—cleared the Japanese first from Papua, then the Mandate and finally from the Dutch colony. The campaign resulted in a crushing defeat and very heavy losses for the Empire of Japan. As in most Pacific War campaigns, disease and starvation claimed more Japanese lives than enemy action. Most Japanese troops never even came into contact with Allied forces, and were instead simply cut off and subjected to an effective blockade by the US Navy. Garrisons were effectively besieged and denied shipments of food and medical supplies, and as a result, some claim that 97% of Japanese deaths in this campaign were from non-combat causes.[https://www.awm.gov.au/journal/j34/stevens.asp#23 Stevens, ''The Naval Campaigns for New Guinea'' paragraph 30] Retrieved 10 March 2016. According to [[John Laffin]], the campaign "was arguably the most arduous fought by any Allied troops during World War II".Laffin 1986, p. 303 ==1942== ===Strategic situation=== [[File:Eastern New Guinea and New Britain 1944.jpg|thumb|480px|Papua New Guinea, the Bismarcks and the Northern Solomons]] The struggle for New Guinea began with the [[Battle of Rabaul (1942)|capture by the Japanese]] of the city of [[Rabaul]] at the northeastern tip of [[New Britain Island]] in January 1942 (the Allies responded with multiple [[Bombing of Rabaul (1942)|bombing raids]], of which the [[Action off Bougainville]] was one). Rabaul overlooks [[Simpson Harbor]], a considerable natural anchorage, and was ideal for the construction of airfields. Over the next year, the Japanese built up the area into a major air and naval base.{{Citation needed|date=September 2015}} The Japanese [[Japanese Eighth Area Army|8th Area Army]] (equivalent to a Euroamerican army), under General [[Hitoshi Imamura]] at Rabaul, was responsible for both the New Guinea and [[Solomon Islands campaign]]s. The [[Japanese Eighteenth Army|Japanese 18th Army]] (equivalent to a Euroamerican corps), under Lieutenant General [[Hatazō Adachi]], was responsible for Japanese operations on mainland New Guinea.{{Citation needed|date=September 2015}} The colonial capital of [[Port Moresby]] on the south coast of Papua was the strategic key for the Japanese in this area of operations. Capturing it would both neutralize the Allies' principal forward base and serve as a springboard for a [[Proposed Japanese invasion of Australia during World War II|possible invasion of Australia]].Morison 1949, p. 10 For the same reasons, General [[Douglas MacArthur]], Supreme Commander Allied Forces [[South West Pacific Area (command)|South West Pacific Area]] was determined to hold it. MacArthur was further determined to conquer all of New Guinea in his progress toward the eventual recapture of the Philippines.Morison 1950, pp. 31–33 General Headquarters [[South West Pacific Area (command)|Southwest Pacific Area]] Operational Instruction No.7 of 25 May 1942, issued by Commander-Allied-Forces, General [[Douglas MacArthur]], placed all Australian and US Army, Air Force and Navy Forces in the Port Moresby Area under the control of [[New Guinea Force]].{{sfn|GHQ SWPA|}} ===Japanese seizure of Lae and Salamaua=== {{Main|Invasion of Lae-Salamaua}} Due north of Port Moresby, on the northeast coast of Papua, are [[Huon Gulf]] and the [[Huon Peninsula]]. The Japanese entered [[Invasion of Lae-Salamaua|Lae and Salamaua]], two locations on Huon Gulf, unopposed in early March 1942.Morison 1950, p. 31 MacArthur would have liked to deny this area to the Japanese, but he had neither sufficient air nor naval forces to undertake a counterlanding. The Japanese at Rabaul and other bases on New Britain would have easily overwhelmed any such effort (by mid-September, MacArthur's entire naval force under Vice Admiral [[Arthur S. Carpender]] consisted entirely of 5 cruisers, 8 destroyers, 20 submarines 7 small craft).Morison 1950, p. 32 The only Allied response was a bombing raid of [[Invasion of Lae-Salamaua|Lae and Salamaua]] by aircraft flying over the [[Owen Stanley Range]] from the carriers {{USS|Lexington|CV-2|6}} and {{USS|Yorktown|CV-5|6}}, leading the Japanese to reinforce these sites. ===Japanese attempt on Port Moresby=== [[Operation Mo]] was the designation given by the Japanese to their initial plan to take possession of Port Moresby. Their operation plan decreed a five-pronged attack: one task force to establish a seaplane base at Tulagi in the lower Solomons, one to establish a seaplane base in the [[Louisiade Archipelago]] off the eastern tip of New Guinea, one of transports to land troops near Port Moresby, one with a [[Light aircraft carrier|light carrier]] to cover the landing, and one with two [[fleet carrier]]s to sink the Allied forces sent in response.Morison 1949, pp. 10–11 In the resulting 4–8 May 1942 [[Battle of the Coral Sea]], the Allies suffered higher losses in ships, but achieved a crucial strategic victory by turning the Japanese landing force back, thereby removing the threat to Port Moresby, at least for the time being.Morison 1949, p. 63 After this failure, the Japanese decided on a longer term, two-pronged assault for their next attempt on Port Moresby. Forward positions would first be established at [[Milne Bay]], located in the forked eastern end of the Papuan peninsula, and at [[Buna, Papua New Guinea|Buna]], a village on the northeast coast of Papua about halfway between [[Huon Gulf]] and Milne Bay. Simultaneous operations from these two locations, one amphibious and one overland, would converge on the target city.Morison 1950, p. 33 ===Crossing the Owen Stanleys=== {{Main|Kokoda Track campaign}} {{quote box | width = 28em | align = left | quote = "[T]he [[Owen Stanley Range]] is a jagged, precipitous obstacle covered with tropical rainforest up to the pass at 6500-foot elevation, and with moss like a thick wet sponge up to the highest peaks, 13,000 feet above the sea. The [[Kokoda Trail]] [was] suitable for splay-toed Papuan aborigines but a torture to modern soldiers carrying heavy equipment..." | source = – Samuel Eliot Morison, ''Breaking the Bismarcks Barrier'', p. 34 }} Buna was easily taken as the Allies had no military presence there (MacArthur wisely chose not to attempt an occupation by paratroopers since any such force would have been easily wiped out by the Japanese). The Japanese [[Invasion of Buna-Gona|occupied the village]] with an initial force of 1,500 on 21 July and by 22 August had 11,430 men under arms at Buna. Then began the grueling [[Kokoda Track campaign]], a brutal experience for both the Japanese and Australian troops involved. On 17 September, the Japanese had reached the village of Ioribaiwa, just {{convert|30|km|-1}} from the Allied airdrome at Port Moresby. The Australians held firm and began their counterdrive on 26 September. "...the Japanese retreat down the Kokoda Trail had turned into a rout. Thousands perished from starvation and disease; the commanding general, [[Tomitarō Horii|Horii]], was drowned."Morison 1950, p. 43 Thus was the overland threat to Port Moresby permanently removed.Morison 1950, pp. 33–34 ===Air operations=== Since Port Moresby was the only port supporting operations in Papua, its defence was critical to the campaign. The air defences consisted of [[Bell P-39 Airacobra|P-39]] and [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk|P-40]] fighters. RAAF [[radar]] could not provide sufficient warning of Japanese attacks, so reliance was placed on [[coastwatchers]] and spotters in the hills until an American radar unit arrived in September with better equipment.Craven & Cate 1948, pp. 476–477. Japanese bombers were often escorted by fighters which came in at {{convert|30000|ft|m|abbr=on}}—too high to be intercepted by the P-39s and P-40s—giving the Japanese an altitude advantage in air combat.Watson 1944, p. 20. The cost to the Allied fighters was high. By June, 20–25 P-39s had been lost in air combat, while three more had been destroyed on the ground and eight had been destroyed in landings by accident. The Australian and American anti-aircraft gunners of the Composite Anti-Aircraft Defences played a crucial part. The gunners got a lot of practice; Port Moresby suffered its 78th raid on 17 August 1942.Watson 1944, p. 31. A gradual improvement in their numbers and skill forced the Japanese bombers up to higher altitude, where they were less accurate, and then, in August, to raiding by night. Although RAAF [[Consolidated PBY Catalina|PBY Catalina]]s and [[Lockheed Hudson]]s were based at Port Moresby, because of the Japanese air attacks, long-range bombers like [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress|B-17s]], [[North American B-25 Mitchell|B-25]]s, and [[Martin B-26 Marauder|B-26]]s could not be safely based there and were instead staged through from bases in Australia. This resulted in considerable fatigue for the air crews. Due to USAAF doctrine and a lack of long-range escorts, long-range bomber raids on targets like Rabaul went in unescorted and suffered heavy losses, prompting severe criticism of [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] [[George Brett (general)|George Brett]] by war correspondents for misusing his forces.Watson 1944, p. 24. But fighters did provide cover for the transports, and for bombers when their targets were within range.Watson 1944, p. 38. Aircraft based at Port Moresby and Milne Bay fought to prevent the Japanese from basing aircraft at Buna, and attempted to prevent the Japanese reinforcement of the Buna area.Watson 1944, pp. 31–33. As the Japanese ground forces pressed toward Port Moresby, the Allied Air Forces struck supply points along the Kokoda Track. Japanese makeshift bridges were attacked by P-40s with {{convert|500|lb|kg|abbr=on}} bombs.Watson 1944, p. 42. ===Allied capture of Milne Bay=== {{Main|Battle of Milne Bay}} {{quote box | width = 32em | align = right | quote = "Thenceforth, the [[Battle of Milne Bay]] became an infantry struggle in the sopping jungle carried on mostly at night under pouring rain. The Aussies were fighting mad, for they had found some of their captured fellows tied to trees and bayoneted to death, surmounted by the placard, 'It took them a long time to die'." | source = – Samuel Eliot Morison, ''Breaking the Bismarcks Barrier'', p. 38 }} While it was beyond MacArthur's capabilities to deny Buna to the Japanese, the same could not be said of [[Milne Bay]], which was easily accessible by Allied naval forces. In early June, US Army engineers, Australian infantry and an anti-aircraft battery were landed near the [[Lever Brothers]] coconut plantation at [[Gili Gili]], and work was begun on an airfield. By 22 August, about 8,500 Australians and 1,300 Americans were on site.Morison 1950, pp. 36–37 The Japanese arrived and the 25 August – 7 September [[Battle of Milne Bay]] was underway. Historian Samuel Eliot Morison summed up the results this way: {{quote|''...the enemy had shot his bolt; he never showed up again in these waters. The Battle for Milne Bay was a small one as World War II engagements went, but very important. Except for the initial assault on Wake Island, this was the first time that a Japanese amphibious operation had been thrown for a loss ... Furthermore, the Milne Bay affair demonstrated once again that an amphibious assault without air protection, and with an assault force inferior to that of the defenders, could not succeed.''Morison 1950, p. 39}} The [[D'Entrecasteaux Islands]] lie directly off the northeast coast of the lower portion of the Papuan peninsula. The westernmost island of this group, [[Goodenough Island|Goodenough]], had been occupied in August 1942 by 353 stranded troops from bombed Japanese landing craft. The destroyer ''Yayoi'', sent to recover these men, was itself bombed and sunk on 11 September. A force of 800 Australian troops [[Battle of Goodenough Island|landed on 22 October]] on either side of the Japanese position. Beleaguered, the survivors of the Japanese garrison were evacuated by submarine on the night of 26 October. The Allies proceeded to turn the island into an air base.Morison 1950, pp. 39–40 ===Allied recapture of Buna and Gona=== {{Main|Battle of Buna-Gona}} {{quote box | width = 28em | align = left | quote = "In the swamp country which surrounded the area were large crocodiles ... Incidence of malaria was almost one hundred per cent. At Sanananda the swamp and jungle were typhus-ridden ... crawling roots reached out into stagnant pools infested with mosquitoes and numerous crawling insects ... every foxhole filled with water. Thompson sub machine-guns jammed with the gritty mud and were unreliable in the humid atmosphere ... " | source = – John Vader, ''New Guinea: The Tide Is Stemmed'', pp. 102–103 }} The Japanese drive to conquer all of New Guinea had been decisively stopped. MacArthur was now determined to liberate the island as a stepping-stone to the reconquest of the Philippines. MacArthur's rollback began with the 16 November 1942 – 22 January 1943 [[Battle of Buna-Gona]]. The experience of the green [[32nd Infantry Division (United States)|US 32nd Infantry Division]], just out of training camp and utterly unschooled in jungle warfare, was nearly disastrous. Instances were noted of officers completely out of their depth, of men eating meals when they should have been on the firing line, even of cowardice. MacArthur relieved the division commander and on 30 November instructed Lieutenant General [[Robert L. Eichelberger]], commander of the [[US I Corps]], to go to the front personally with the charge "to remove all officers who won't fight ... if necessary, put sergeants in charge of battalions ... I want you to take Buna, or not come back alive."Vader, p. 90 {{quote box | quote = "Also formidable was the tenacity of the enemy, who would fight to the death in these stinking holes, starving, diseased and with their dead rotting and unburied beside them." | source = – John Vader, ''New Guinea: The Tide Is Stemmed'', p. 93 | align = right | width = 26em }} The [[7th Division (Australia)|Australian 7th Division]] under the command of Major General [[George Alan Vasey]], along with the revitalized US 32nd Division, restarted the Allied offensive. Gona fell to the Australians on 9 December 1942, Buna to the US 32nd on 2 January 1943, and [[Sanananda]], located between the two larger villages, fell to the Australians on 22 January.Vader, p. 102 [[Operation Lilliput]] (18 December 1942 – June 1943) was an ongoing resupply operation ferrying troops and supplies from [[Milne Bay]], at the tip of the [[Papua New Guinea|Papuan Peninsula]], to [[Oro Bay]], a little more than halfway between Milne Bay and the [[Buna-Gona campaign|Buna-Gona]] area. ==1943== ===Holding Wau=== {{Main|Battle of Wau}} [[File:Deadjapanese.jpg|thumb|Two dead Japanese soldiers in a water filled shell hole somewhere in New Guinea]] [[Wau, Papua New Guinea|Wau]] is a village in the interior of the Papuan peninsula, approximately {{convert|50|km|-1}} southwest of [[Salamaua]]. An airfield had been built there during an area gold rush in the 1920s and 1930s. This airfield was of great value to the Australians during the fighting for northeast Papua.Morison 1950, p. 54 Once the Japanese had decided to give up on [[Battle of Guadalcanal|Guadalcanal]], the capture of Port Moresby loomed even larger in their strategic thinking. Taking the airfield at Wau was a crucial step in this process, and to this end, the [[Japanese 51st Division|51st Division]] was transferred from Indochina and placed under General [[Hitoshi Imamura]]'s [[Japanese Eighth Area Army|Eighth Area Army]] at Rabaul; one regiment arrived at Lae in early January 1943. In addition, about 5,400 survivors of the Japanese defeat at [[Battle of Buna-Gona|Buna-Gona]] were moved into the Lae-Salamaua area. Opposing these forces were the Australian [[2/5th Battalion (Australia)|2/5th]], [[2/6th Battalion (Australia)|2/6th]] and [[2/7th Battalion (Australia)|2/7th Battalions]] along with Lieutenant Colonel Norman Fleay's [[Kanga Force]].Vader, p. 106 The Australians decisively turned back the Japanese assault in the ensuing 29–31 January 1943 [[Battle of Wau]]. "Within a few days, the enemy was retreating from the Wau Valley, where he had suffered a serious defeat, harassed all the way back to Mubo..."Vader, p. 108 About one week later, the Japanese completed their [[Guadalcanal Campaign#Ke evacuation|evacuation of Guadalcanal]]. ===Final Japanese drive on Wau=== {{Main|Battle of the Bismarck Sea}} General Imamura and his naval counterpart at [[Rabaul]], Admiral [[Jinichi Kusaka]], commander [[Southeast Area Fleet]], resolved to reinforce their ground forces at [[Lae]] for one final all-out attempt against Wau. If the transports succeeded in staying behind a weather front and were protected the whole way by fighters from the various airfields surrounding the [[Bismarck Sea]], they might make it to Lae with an acceptable level of loss, i.e., at worst half the task force would be sunk en route.Morison 1950, pp. 54–55 It is indicative of the extent to which Japanese ambitions had fallen at this point in the war that a 50% loss of ground troops aboard ship was considered acceptable. [[File:A20BismarckSea.jpg|thumb|An Allied A-20 bomber attacks Japanese shipping during the Battle of the Bismarck Sea, March, 1943]] Three factors conspired to create disaster for the Japanese. First, they had woefully underestimated the strength of the Allied air forces. Second, the Allies had become convinced that the Japanese were preparing a major seaborne reinforcement and so had stepped up their air searches. Most important of all, the bombers of MacArthur's air forces, under the command of Lieutenant General [[George Kenney|George C. Kenney]], had been modified to enable new offensive tactics. Their noses had been refitted with eight 50-caliber machine guns for strafing slow-moving ships on the high seas. In addition, their bomb bays were filled with 500-pound bombs to be used in the newly devised practice of [[skip bombing]].Morison 1950, pp. 56–57 About 6,900 troops aboard eight transports, escorted by eight destroyers, departed Rabaul at midnight 28 February under the command of Rear Admiral [[Masatomi Kimura]].Morison 1950, p. 55 Through the afternoon of 1 March, the overcast weather held at which point everything began to go wrong for the Japanese. The weather changed direction and Kimura's slow-moving task force was spotted by an Allied scout plane. By the time the Allied bombers and PT boats finished their work on 3 March, Kimura had lost all eight transports and four of his eight destroyers.Morison 1950, pp. 58–62 {{quote box | width = 24em | align = left | quote = " 'The Boeing [B-25] is most terrifying,' wrote one survivor in his diary. 'We are repeating the failure of Guadalcanal. Most regrettable!!' " | source = – Samuel Eliot Morison, ''Breaking the Bismarcks Barrier'', p. 60 }} {{quote|''...planes and PTs went about the sickening business of killing survivors in boats, rafts or wreckage. Fighters mercilessly strafed anything on the surface ... The PTs turned their guns on, and hurled depth charges at the three boats which, with over a hundred men on board, sank. It was a grisly task, but a military necessity since Japanese soldiers do not surrender and within swimming distance of shore, they could not be allowed to land and join the Lae garrison.Morison 1950, p. 62}} The remaining destroyers with about 2,700 surviving troops limped back to Rabaul. "The enemy never again risked a transport larger than a small coaster or barge in waters shadowed by American planes. His contemplated offensive against Wau died a-borning."Morison 1950, p. 62 ===Operation I-Go=== {{Main|Operation I-Go}} {{multiple image | direction = horizontal | width = 105 | header = Combined Fleet, Third Fleet and Southeast Area Commanders | image1 = Isoroku Yamamoto.jpg | caption1 = Fleet Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto | image2 = Ozawa11.jpg | caption2 = Vice Admiral Jisaburo Ozawa | image3 = Jinichi Kusaka.jpg | caption3 = Rear Admiral Jinichi Kusaka }} Fleet Admiral [[Isoroku Yamamoto]] promised [[Hirohito|the emperor]] that he would pay back the Allies for the [[Battle of the Bismarck Sea|disaster at the Bismarck Sea]] with a series of massive air strikes. For this, he ordered the air arm of Vice Admiral [[Jisaburo Ozawa|Jisaburo Ozawa's]] [[Third Fleet (Imperial Japanese Navy)|Third Fleet]] carriers to reinforce the [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service#Eleventh Air Fleet and land-based air fleets|Eleventh Air Fleet]] at Rabaul. To demonstrate the seriousness of the effort to the [[Supreme War Council]], multiple shifts of high-ranking personnel were also effected: Both Yamamoto and Ozawa moved their headquarters to Rabaul; and [[IJN 8th Fleet|Eighth Fleet]] commander Vice Admiral [[Gunichi Mikawa]] as well as General Imamura's chief of staff were sent to Tokyo with advice and explanations for the respective General Staffs (Admiral [[Tomoshige Samejima]] replaced Mikawa as Eight Fleet commander).Morison 1950, pp. 117–118 I-Go was to be carried out in two phases, one against the lower Solomons and one against Papua. {{quote box | width = 28em | align = left | quote = "At 1400 the Russell Island radar screen became milky with traces of bogeys and Guadalcanal broadcast "Condition Red," followed shortly by an unprecedented "Condition ''Very'' Red." | source = – Samuel Eliot Morison, ''Breaking the Bismarcks Barrier'', p. 120 }} The first strike, on 7 April, was against Allied shipping in the [[Ironbottom Sound|waters between Guadalcanal and Tulagi]]. At 177 planes, this was the largest Japanese air attack since [[Pearl Harbor Attack|Pearl Harbor]].Morison 1950, pp. 120–123 Yamamoto then turned his attention to New Guinea: 94 planes struck [[Oro Bay]] on 11 April; 174 planes hit [[Port Moresby]] on 12 April; and in the largest raid of all, 188 aircraft struck [[Milne Bay]] on 14 April.Morison 1950, pp. 125–126 I-Go demonstrated that the Japanese command was not learning the lessons of air power that the Allies were. The Allied [[Bombing of Rabaul (November 1943)|reduction of Rabaul]] was only made possible by relentless air strikes that took place day after day, but Yamamoto thought the damage inflicted by a few attacks of large formations would derail Allied plans long enough for Japan to prepare a defense in depth. Also, Yamamoto accepted at face value his fliers' over-optimistic reports of damage: they reported a score of one cruiser, two destroyers and 25 transports, as well as 175 Allied planes, a figure that should certainly have aroused some skepticism. Actual Allied losses amounted to one destroyer, one oiler, one corvette, two cargo ships and approximately 25 aircraft.Morison 1950, pp. 127 These meager results were not commensurate with either the resources expended or the expectations that had been promoted. ===Allied strategy toward Rabaul=== {{Main|Operation Cartwheel}} The umbrella term for the series of strategic actions taken by the Allies to reduce and capture the vast Japanese naval and air facilities at [[Rabaul]] was [[Operation Cartwheel]]. Two major moves were planned for the end of June: * Turner's III 'Phib undertook [[Operation Toenails]], the invasion of the [[New Georgia Islands]] halfway up the [[Solomon Islands|Solomons]] chain (30 June – 7 October 1943). * Barbey's VII 'Phib carried out two almost simultaneous undertakings. [[Operation Chronicle]], the capture of the [[Trobriand Islands]] between Papua and the [[Solomon Islands|Solomons]] (22 – 30 June 1943), and the landing of a combined American/Australian force at [[Landing at Nassau Bay|Nassau Bay]] on the Papuan coast just south of [[Huon Gulf]] (30 June – 6 July 1943).Morison 1950, pp. 132–133 Eventually, the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] realized that a landing and siege of "Fortress Rabaul" would be far too costly, and that the Allies' ultimate strategic purposes could be achieved by simply neutralizing and bypassing it. At the [[Quebec Conference, 1943|Quebec Conference]] in August 1943, the leaders of the Allied nations agreed to this change in strategy. revision.text:
'''Ogbunabali''' ([[Igbo language|Igbo]]: ''Ogbúnàbàlị̀'' [He] kills at night) is the traditional [[Igbo_people|Igbo]] [[Death deity]]. His name is considered to be a literal description of his character as he is said to kill his victims in the night, these usually being criminals or those who have committed an unspeakable [[taboo]].
{{Odinani}}
[[Category:Igbo gods]] [[Category:African gods]] [[Category:Death gods]]
{{Africa-myth-stub}} [[ig:Ogbunabali]]

The '''Parenteral Drug Association''' ('''PDA''') is an international [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]] [[industry trade group]] for [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceutical]] and [[biopharmaceutical]] manufacturers. Founded in 1946 as the Parenteral Drug Association by a small group of pharmaceutical manufacturers who recognized the need for an organization to disseminate technical information within the industry, it now has more than 11,000 members worldwide. Today, coordinated through its headquarters and its Training & Research Institute in Bethesda, Maryland, PDA volunteers worldwide promote the exchange of rapidly evolving information on the latest technology and regulations concerning high-quality pharmaceutical production.{{cite web|title=About PDA|url=https://www.pda.org/footer/about-pda|website=Parenteral Drug Association|accessdate=8 October 2015}} ==Global Organization== PDA has members in 74 countries and regions:
'''Africa'''
Botswana, Egypt, Ghana, South Africa, Tunisia, Zimbabwe '''Asia'''
Bangladesh, China, India, Pakistan '''Caribbean, Central, & South America'''
Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Paraguay Peru, Uruguay '''Europe'''
Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Kazakhstan, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Ukraine, United Kingdom '''Middle East'''
Cyprus, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Turkey, United Arab Emirates '''North America'''
Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, United States '''Pacific-Rim'''
Australia, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Pharmaceutical industry trade groups]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:International organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1946]]
